standfirst:
The Red Road flats in Glasgow were once home to more than 4,500 people. Now most of the blocks have been emptied and demolition has begun. Jamal, a failed Iraqi Kurdish asylum seeker, lived alone in one block for several months, refusing to move out. If he did, he feared eviction from the UK; if he returned to his homeland, he believed he would be killed

The Bird Man of Red Road has been shortlisted for a Scottish Refugee Council Media Award

http://www.chrisleslie.com
headline: The Bird Man of Red Road: the story behind the Glasgow flats' last resident - video

standfirst: When Nato eventually intervened in 1999 to stop the ethnic cleansing by Serbian forces of ethnic Albanians in Kosovo, the UK prime minister Tony Blair was hailed as a hero. As refugees returned to the province, several new parents of baby boys called their sons Tony Blair. Now, fifteen years on, the Guardian's Julian Borger returns to Kosovo to hear how their lives have turned out – and their hopes for the future of a fledgling state still struggling for full international recognition
headline: Little Tony Blairs of Kosovo: the boys named after the 'great man' – video

standfirst: A Jordanian court ruled on Thursday that international terror suspect Abu Qatada is not guilty of terrorism offences relating to an alleged 1998 bomb plot. The UK sent the radical Islamist cleric back to Amman in 2013 on the promise that the court would not use evidence obtained by torture. Qatada will receive the verdict for a second set of charges later in the year
headline: Radical Islamist cleric Abu Qatada cleared of terrorism offences in Jordan - video

standfirst: Politicians say a statue of Mahatma Gandhi will be unveiled in Parliament Square in London. In India to meet the country's new prime minister, they say the statue will be a 'monument of the friendship between Britain and India' and say his  lessons of peace between communities and non-violent protests are as relevant today as they were in his own time. Britain will put up a statue to the father of the world's largest democracy in 'the most prominent place that we can'
headline: George Osborne and William Hague announce new statue of Gandhi during visit to India – video

standfirst: The shadow justice minister Sadiq Khan says more needs to be done to prevent British Muslims from going to the Middle East to fight. Khan says Muslims in the UK need to know the real version of Islam to resist extremist messages. The shadow justice minister adds that it only takes one person to continue violent behaviour in this country for there to be danger to Brits. Khan's comments come after British Islamists in Iraq released a video to recruit others
headline: Sadiq Khan: British Muslims need to resist extremist messages - video

standfirst: The prime minister says the security services need to listen to someone's phone and read their emails to stop terrorist plots; to do this the government relies on help from internet and telephone companies. The new laws he introduces strengthen their powers to do this, he says, and will also help in the fight against child abuse and other serious crimes. He says he 'will not  stand by' and watch foreign companies become less willing to share private information with the government
headline: David Cameron explains why new surveillance laws are needed and what they will allow – video
